image.altText: Steve Smith has a frustrated look on his face as he walks off the field

items.synopsis: Australia resumes its second batting innings with a lead of 221 runs over England on day four at Lord's. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Australia stutter in the pursuit of a massive lead on day four at Lord's

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One brings two! Smith goes on the hook, gets a top edge to Zak Crawley in the deep and he takes a simple catch! Smith goes for 34 off 61! That's got the crowd going a bit.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: OUT! SMITH GOES TOO!

children.content: One brings two!
(Getty Images)
Smith goes on the hook, gets a top edge to Zak Crawley in the deep and he takes a simple catch!
Smith goes for 34 off 61!
That's got the crowd going a bit.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Usman Khawaja has holed out to the sub fielder Matthew Potts in the deep! That's, dare I say it, a very English dismissal against the short ball (of which there were far more than two in that over). He goes for 77 from 187 balls.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: KHAWAJA IS OUT!

children.content: Usman Khawaja has holed out to the sub fielder Matthew Potts in the deep!
(Getty Images)
That's, dare I say it, a very English dismissal against the short ball (of which there were far more than two in that over).
He goes for 77 from 187 balls.

image.altText: People stand on a stage.

items.synopsis: The prestigious National NAIDOC Week Awards Ceremony is underway in Brisbane and 10 winners will soon be recognised for their triumphs.

title.children: Shark researcher, former AFL star and dedicated elders among NAIDOC Week Awards winners

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Worimi man Professor Kelvin Kong has been named the 2023 NAIDOC Person of the Year. The ENT surgeon was nominated by his colleague Toni Manton. She said seeing his work in surgery is "absolutely unbelievable". "Professor Kong has been instrumental in Aboriginal health, you know. "Not only as being the first Aboriginal surgeon,he's instrumental in research as well. "Aboriginal health in Aboriginalhands is the way of the future." Mr Kong told the crowd he was proud to be accepting the award on behalf of his community. "There are so many people who do so much work in this space that don't get this kind of platform to talk about it and share their experience so I do want to acknowledge and pay my respects to them— you have done such amazing work in this space," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The 2023 NAIDOC Person of the Year is Australia's first Indigenous surgeon

children.content: Worimi man Professor Kelvin Kong has been named the
2023 NAIDOC Person of the Year.

props.alt: A screenshot from ABC TV of Kelvin Kong

children.content: (ABC)
The ENT surgeon was nominated by his colleague Toni Manton.
She said seeing his work in surgery is "absolutely unbelievable".
"Professor Kong has been instrumental in Aboriginal health, you know.
"Not only as being the first Aboriginal surgeon,he's instrumental in research as well.
"Aboriginal health in Aboriginalhands is the way of the future."
Mr Kong told the crowd he was proud to be accepting the award on behalf of his community.

"There are so many people who do so much work in this space that don't get this kind of platform to talk about it and share their experience so I do want to acknowledge and pay my respects to them— you have done such amazing work in this space," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Accepting this award is a huge honour," says Tony McCartney, chairperson of Bubup Wilam Aboriginal Child and Family Centre. "Bubup Wilam's philosophy is about creating a sovereign space to look after our own children and families. This award demonstrates that we are on the right track. "We will continue to strive for our children and families. We need to invest into our future for our children; let's not waste their first six years, let's build on the strength and depth of our histories and belonging. "In the words of the great doctor Bruce McGuinness, he said, 'give us your today and we will give you our tomorrow'." Truth-telling underpins the learning curriculum at Bubup Wilam Aboriginal Child and Family Centre. The centre services Aboriginal children aged to five, with its name meaning 'Childrens' Place' in the Woi Wurrung language. Their approach to learning on country empowers young Aboriginal children to develop strong connections with their identity and their culture. Bubup Wilam Aboriginal Child and Family Centre is also one of three service providers in Australia to offer a one-stop shop for allied health services like: hearing tests, speech pathologists, general check-ups without fear, shame, racism.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Childrens' Place' recognised in Education Award

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As the daughter of civil rights powerhouse, Charles Perkins, Rachel Perkins didn't walk in her father's shadow. Instead, she blazed a trail of her own, truth-telling the history of Australia that many Australians didn't hear at school, through her award-winning films and TV programs. Much of the Arrernte and Kalkadoon writer, producer and director's career, spans over 30 years, unearthing Australia's history through the eyes and voices of First Nations people. Her seven-part series, First Australians, received notable industry awards including the UN Media Peace Prize, TV Week Logie Award and an Australian Writers and Directors Guild Award. Not only was it Australia's bestselling educational title, but it sold out across the world. When accepting the Creative Talent award, Perkins paid tribute to Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney and last year's Lifetime Achievement award-winner Pat Anderson. "These two women are leading us with the Uluru Statement from the Heart, and we're taking Australia on a journey to 'Yes' this year — stand with us, Australia," she said. Reporting by Tahnee Jash
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rachel Perkins is creative talent of the year

and we're taking Australia on a journey to 'Yes' this year — stand with us, Australia," she said.
Reporting by Tahnee Jash

image.altText: Albanese smiles in the cold dawn light, the warm colour of a grand autumnal tree fills the background behind him.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese believes Australians will welcome the news of a larger than expected budget surplus even as their own budgets continue to take a battering.

title.children: Prime minister spruiks large budget surplus as Australian households battle cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: - A person walks past a building which says Fox News.

items.synopsis: The payout to Abby Grossberg will settle all litigation she brought against Fox Corporation, Fox News Network and her former co-workers, including former Fox host Tucker Carlson.

title.children: Fox News reaches $18 million settlement with former producer who testified in Dominion case

image.altText: a woman wearing a suit looks sideways

items.synopsis: News headlines about the corruption watchdog's findings against Gladys Berejiklian this week left many scratching their heads and wondering why she won't face any criminal charges for her conduct.

title.children: AFL live: Bombers hearts broken by Port Adelaide after Magpies masterclass, Crows and Bulldogs win

image.altText: A group of helmeted police officers walk with riot shields during a protest, lit by bright yellow street light.

items.synopsis: France's interior ministry says the fourth night of clashes between mostly young protesters and police was less violent than the previous night but more arrests were made, as President Emmanuel Macron urges parents to keep their kids off the streets and the government asks social media companies to help identify those fomenting violence.

title.children: French police arrest almost 1,000 people in fourth night of unrest

image.altText: Afghanistan evacuation

title.children: Review into evacuation of US troops from Afghanistan critical of Biden, Trump

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

title.children: The army major general turned federal anti-corruption boss officially starts today — what's ahead of him?

image.altText: a cloud band forms over the kimberley

items.synopsis: Unseasonable rain continues to fall across Australia's north in what's meant to be the region's dry season, helping lower temperatures to near-record levels.

title.children: Why holiday-makers heading north for winter sun could be in for unpleasant surprise

image.altText: Aboriginal man with Aboriginal flag on a blue T-shirt on a balcony with the beach behind him.

image.altText: The window of an Apple store with a large Apple logo on it

image.altText: Bright red lines coming out the top of a mountian.

image.altText: bus crash

items.synopsis: At least 25 people die after a bus crashes and bursts into flames in India's western state of Maharashtra.

image.altText: Vladimir Putin's face is lit by warm sunlight. He wears dark sunglasses and a black jacket on black shirt

image.altText: A woman resting her chin on her hand smiles at the camera.

This is how mid-career professionals jumped at the chance for an occupation transformation and set themselves up for a more fulfilling work future.

title.children: Would you take a $50,000 pay cut? Why these mid-career professionals aren't looking back

image.altText: A woman dressed in purple holding flowers supported by friends and family in purple

title.children: 'I've waited 24 years for this': Michelle Bright's mother in tears as Dubbo court convicts killer

image.altText: Two women stand in front of an apple display at a supermarket and put them in a small plastic bag.

items.synopsis: The government is expanding a campaign against single-use plastics that it started in 2019, when it banned the thicker plastic shopping bags that customers used to carry home their grocery items.

title.children: New Zealand says it's the first to ban thin plastic bags from supermarkets

image.altText: Two men in suits walk down a footpath, one in front of the other. The one in front is shielding his face with a clipboard.

items.synopsis: The ex-officer has been found guilty in Lismore District Court of knowingly having sex with a child under the age of 16.

title.children: Jury finds former NSW police officer guilty of sex with minor

image.altText: A bald man looking at the camera

image.altText: Girl looking straight at camera with spinifex bush in background.
